Dear Ms. Santer:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
FOR CWL ONLY
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and
your contract.

ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that a resident was not receiving a prescribed medication as ordered. It
is also alleged that the resident was not receiving weekly blood draws to monitor the
prescribed medication.
INVESTIGATION:
On April 15, 2020 DCWL received the complaint as outlined above. I initiated a
special investigation on the same day. The complainant was interviewed as well as
agency staff. Documents were received and reviewed as well as the file of Resident
A, the alleged victim in this case. What follows is information obtained from the
aforementioned sources.
On April 15, 16, 17, 2020, the Complainant was interviewed by telephone. The
Complainant is the foster care worker for Resident A. The Complainant offered the
following information. Resident A is a 15 year old female who was placed at
Teaching Family Homes South Bluff program in Marquette from March 10, 2020 and
was replaced to the Kids First program in Grand Rapids on April 13, 2020. The
complainant reported that while Resident A was placed at Teaching Family Home
3

(TFH) she was not receiving a prescribed psychotropic medication, (Clozapine) and
in addition, she was not receiving weekly blood draws to monitor the medication.
The Complainant reported that Resident A had received only one blood draw while
in the care of TFH and that occurred on March 27, 2020. The Complainant reported
that weekly blood draws were medically ordered to monitor the levels of the
Clozapine medication. The Complainant reported additionally that when Resident A
arrived to the Kids First program there was not a transfer of the prescribed clozapine
psychotropic medication to Kids First, indicating that it had run out and Resident A
had not been receiving it while placed at TFH. The Complainant reported that she
sent an email on March 12, 2020 to the social service worker at TFH and the
consulting physician assistant for the agency, in which she informed them that
Resident A requires weekly blood draws to monitor the clozapine medication. The
Complainant also reported that March 10, 2020, when she dropped off Resident A at
TFH she provided agency staff with the blood draw order. Upon my request, the
Complainant forwarded to me emails between she and staff at TFH as well as
medical reports and information for Resident A.
On April 15, 2020 and April 16, 2020, the Chief Administrator for Teaching Family
Homes was interviewed by telephone. During the April 15, 2020 interview the Chief
Administrator reported that blood draws had been occurring by the medical facility
Upper Great Lakes Family Health in Marquette. The Chief Administrator did not
know if the prescribed clozapine had been forwarded to the Kids First program and
perhaps it had been left behind at the agency. The Chief Administrator referred me
to the supervisor for the South Bluff program for further information. During the April
16, 2020 phone conversation with the Chief Administrator she reported that she had
investigated the situation further and confirmed that Resident A’s clozapine had run
out while she was placed in the program and it was not refilled. The Chief
Administrator reported that Resident A had been without the medication for about
two weeks and only 1 blood draw had occurred, on March 27, 2020. The Chief
Administrator referred me to the contracted physician assistant that provides medical
services for residents at the program. I requested and received from the Chief
Administrator medication logs for Resident A during her stay at the program.
On April 17, 2020 and June 11, 2020, Staff 1, a Lead Direct Care Staff was
interviewed by telephone. Staff 1 reported that Resident A’s clozapine medication
was contained in bubble packs with other medications. Staff 1 reported that bubble
packs containing Resident A’s medications did not list clozapine however this
medication was listed on the medication logs.
On May 8, and May 13, 2020, the Physician Assistant was interviewed by telephone.
The Physician Assistant reported that she did not change or stop medication for
Resident A and had no idea why or how clozapine was stopped. The Physician
Assistant reported that she does not review medication logs. The Physician
Assistant reported that medications come in bubble packs and the clozapine might
have run out and staff would not know this as there are often several medications in
a bubble pack. The Physician Assistant reported that agency staff had informed her
4

that weekly blood draws are required for Resident A and so she ordered 1 blood
draw for monitoring Lithium blood levels and received the results on March 27, 2020
and reported that nothing abnormal was noted. During the interview on May 8, 2020,
the Physician Assistant reported that weekly blood draw monitoring for clozapine is
not needed.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
A review of Teaching Family Homes medication logs for Resident A from March 10,
2020 to April 13, 2020, were reviewed. A review of the log for March indicates that
clozapine was not administered to Resident A on March 12, 15, 17, 18, 24, 25, 27,
and 28, 2020. A review of the log for April indicates that clozapine was not
administered to Resident A on April 2, 3, 4, 9, 10, 11, 12, 2020.
A document from Network180 (Kent County’s CMH) located in Grand Rapids, dated
December 12, 2019, and signed by the psychiatrist, ordered weekly blood draws for
6 months for Resident A.
A Well Child Exam dated March 24, 2020 conducted by the Physician Assistant lists
medications for Resident A which includes the clozapine medication.
An email from the agency Chief Administrator dated April 15, 2020 acknowledges
that Resident A had not been receiving the clozapine medication for approximately
two weeks and it was not refilled by the agency.
An email dated March 12, 2020 from the Complainant to the agency Social Service
Worker and the agency contracted Physician Assistant informs them of the medically
required weekly blood draws to monitor the clozapine medication and the blood
draws needed to continue for 6 months.
A review of the file for Resident A provided the following information. The file
indicates that Resident A was first prescribed clozapine on August 29, 2019. An
Updated Service Plan dated March 31, 2020 refers to the required weekly blood
draws for Resident A.
On April 24, 2020 and June 11, 2020, Teaching Family Homes intake packet for
Resident A was reviewed. The packet contained the following information:
1. The Network180 physician ordered weekly blood draws.
2. A DHHS document titled “Prescription Medication” which listed the clozapine
medication.
3. Resident A’s medical passport which documents clozapine medication.
5

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
(e) Dispensing medication.
ANALYSIS: The emails from the Complainant to the agency Social Service
Worker and the Physician Assistant document that the agency
was notified upon intake of Resident A’s clozapine medication
as well as the medically ordered blood draws. Intake packet
information also established that the agency was aware of
Resident A’s medical needs upon her placement into the
program.
Medication logs established that Resident A was not receiving
her clozapine medication on a daily basis as prescribed. There
was a document that indicates that only 1 blood draw was
conducted during her month long stay at the program.
The Chief Administrator acknowledged that Resident A was
without her clozapine medication for about 2 weeks and only 1
blood draw was conducted.
The agency failed to provide medically ordered routine medical
care and the dispensing of a prescribed medication.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan the recommendation is for the
continuance of the regular license.
